awd_titl_txt: IRES Cambodia: Mechatronics For Humanitarian Remediation of Explosive Remnants Of War
awd_abstract_narration:
Explosive remnants of war (ERW) present a significant issue for Cambodia and other low-income countries. In response to this problem, the field of humanitarian ERW remediation seeks to detect, dispose, and even recycle ERW with the goal of rendering the ERW-contaminated land safe. Thus, these activities are of critical importance to the growth of affected nations and safety of their people. This international research experiences for students (IRES) program is focused on using mechatronics - a field which integrates mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, control systems engineering, and computer science - to develop solutions for the humanitarian ERW remediation community. This program, run from Villanova University (VU), will send 6 students - at least 2 of which will be graduate students - to do research in Cambodia, one of the most ERW contaminated countries in the world. These students will undertake a 10 week long summer program, including 7.5 weeks in-country. While in Cambodia, the students will collaborate with researchers affiliated with the Institute of Technology of Cambodia (ITC) - the premiere technical university in Cambodia - and the Golden West Humanitarian Foundation (GWHF) - one of the world leaders in humanitarian ERW remediation research and development. In addition to the main research goal of finding mechatronic solutions to problems in the humanitarian ERW remediation community, the program will also serve to 1) strengthen an existing VU-GWHF collaboration, 2) develop globally-engaged engineering researchers and 3) introduce future leaders in engineering research to humanitarian engineering issues. 

The proposed research program will focus on difficult, real-world problems in the area of humanitarian ERW remediation. Projects will be jointly agreed upon by the researchers at VU, ITC, and GWHF. Potential projects include robotic non-technical and/or technical survey for area reduction, automated visual inspection of ordinance, and communications for explosive ordnance disposal (EOD). In general, the fundamental research in this project has the potential to impact mechatronics in a number of ways, including advancements to novel robotics platforms, advanced control and search algorithms, new sensors and sensing strategies, swarm robotics algorithms, and communications.

por.por_cntn:
Project goals: The goals of this International Research Experience for Students (IRES) project are:

To use mechatronics, a field that integrates mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, control systems engineering, and computer science to develop solutions for the humanitarian explosive ordnance disposal (EOD) community. This is motivated by the driving question: "Why haven't the positive effects of mechatronics been felt in humanitarian engineering?" Research performed as a part of this IRES program will focus on advancing the field of mechatronics for humanitarian EOD by studying a broad range of fundamental research topics in this context.

To develop globally-engaged engineering researchers aware of humanitarian research issues. During the summer-long IRES program in Cambodia, selected students worked in an international, interdisciplinary setting and had significant opportunities to engage with international research culture. In addition, by working in a low-income country (Cambodia) on humanitarian engineering issues, students gained insight into the unique constraints that exist when engineering in this context, for example cost constraints and availability and/or quality of materials.

Impact, Merit, and Outcomes: During the course of this project, a total of 18 students (4 graduate and 14 undergraduate students) lived and worked in Cambodia over summer. Students worked on projects with our partners at the Institute of Technology of Cambodia, the premiere technological university in Cambodia, and the Golden West Humanitarian Foundation, a leader in research and development for the humanitarian demining community. 10 additional students (funded from other sources) provided support to the project bud did not travel.

Projects: Specific projects included:

1) A low-cost explosive ordnance disposal (EOD) robot

2) A nodding lidar platform

3) A drone-based solar tracker to enable longer drone missions

4) An oxy-lance system bomb disposal system

5) Integration of an RTK GPS with the robot for high resolution localization

6) Implementation of a magnetometer-based mine detection sensor package

7) Development of software to process the mine detector data

8) Implementation of lidar to increase situational awareness for EOD robot operators

9) Autonomy package for an EOD robot

10) Low-cost gas dearmer

11) Lidar drone for survey

12) Snake-bot for mine detection

13) Development of a drone-based robot tracking sensor.

Scientific Contributions: These projects, although centered on technology development, produced a number of scientific advancements in: 

1) Nodding lidar systems: theoretical and experimental work led to methods to optimize nodding lidar trajectories in order to improve lidar sensor resolution.

2) Robotic platform development and analysis: at the core of many of the projects are two robot platforms: a low-cost EOD robot and a screw-driven "snake" robot.  Analysis of these platforms led to the application of advanced control techniques for autonomy.

3) Magnetometer for mine detection: An existing magnetometer was implemented for mine detection from a ground-based platform (previous work used aerial deployment).       

These contributions have been presented in more than 10 scientific papers, posters, and presentations.

Commercialization: In addition to the technological and theoretical contributions made by the participants in the project, a company has been started to commercialize the EOD robot partially developed in this work. The robot will be available for sale at a price-point that will enable it to be used by humanitarian EOD groups.
